abstract: Apple intends to charge current Leopard owners $29 for the Snow Leopard version. The company sells millions of copies of Mac OS X. So why on earth would it leave so much money on the table?
snippet: Apple intends to charge current Leopard owners $29 for the Snow Leopard version. The company sells millions of copies of Mac OS X. So why on earth would it leave so much money on the table?
lead_paragraph: Apple announced and demonstrated all kinds of things this past Monday at its developers' conference: upgraded laptops, a new iPhone, a new iPhone software suite for all iPhone owners, its new Mac OS X 10.6 "Snow Leopard" operating system, and so on. Lots of goodness, for sure. But to me, one of the most mind-blowing revelations was a single statistic: 29.

headline.main: Snow Leopard Takes a Page From the App Store Playbook
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue
